heroSection.title: Create a methodology on Regen Registry.
heroSection.description: We are working hard to promote integrity and innovation in the methods used to monitor ecosystems and invite any and all methodology designers to take part in expanding this body of work.

stepCardSection.title: General process for creating a new methodology
stepCardSection.mainDescription: A lot can go into writing a new methodology and it might seem like an overwhelming process, but we’re here to help! Check out our CarbonPlus Grasslands Methodology to get a feel for what a methodology might entail and the various components included, and feel free to email science@regen.network for any additional questions.
stepCardSection.bottomTitle: Help develop a range of methodologies for the diversity of nature based solutions
stepCardSection.bottomDescription: In addition to developing methodologies focused on carbon reduction and removal, we must also work to incorporate protocols to track water cycles, nutrient cycles, biodiversity, pollution management, changing weather patterns, and more.

stepCards.title: Check if there is an approved methodology listed on one of the accepted programs
stepCards.description: Prior to developing a methodology, take a look to see if there is a similar methodology that is already approved on our program or other accepted programs. View our list of accepted programs»

stepCards.title: Generate an idea for a methodology and submit a concept note for internal review
stepCards.description: A concept note is a short proposal of an idea for a project or methodology which could be used to address environmental and societal challenges and provide human well-being and ecological benefits.

faqs.question: What to include in your concept note?
faqs.answer: We invite you to share your idea for a nature based solution and we can work together to refine it. Your concept note can include the management activities your concept applies to (cover cropping, rotational grazing, etc.), a high level summary of the indicators being measured, and the monitoring approach.

faqs.question: Where to start:
faqs.answer: Methodology Concept Note Template

stepCards.title: Create a methodology draft and submit it for internal review
stepCards.description: Your methodology should aim to outline standards and tools to monitor the ecological, environmental, and social indicators covered by your nature based solution. Your approach can be region specific or cover a wide range of locations.

faqs.question: What is the internal review process?
faqs.answer: Upon submission, the Regen Network Science Team will conduct an initial review to ensure all the proper information for monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) is included in your methodology. Feedback with suggested upgrades to your methodology will be provided after which the method will be accepted in beta form.

faqs.question: How complete does my draft need to be?
faqs.answer: The draft should include all the information needed for the MRV, however this process can also be used as an opportunity to work with the science community to refine your ideas and develop tools.

stepCards.title: Methodology accepted in beta form
stepCards.description: Methodologies that exist in beta form have not undergone any external review by experts or community members.

faqs.question: Can you run projects in beta form?
faqs.answer: The draft should include all the information needed for the MRV, however this process can also be used as an opportunity to work with the science community to refine your ideas and develop tools.

faqs.question: How does a methodology move out of the beta form?
faqs.answer: Methodologies move out of beta form after a scientific peer review. See step 5 for more details.

stepCards.title: Scientific peer review and public comment, updates made to beta methodology
stepCards.description: After internal review, it may be recommended that some methods undergo external review to ensure the methodology is supported by the scientific community. See our Methodology Review Process for more information.

faqs.question: How long does a scientific peer review take?
faqs.answer: The timeline for scientific peer review can vary. It is up to the methodology designer to drive the peer review process, however we expect this process to take anywhere from one and a half to two months depending on the speed of the reviewers.

faqs.question: What is the public comment period?
faqs.answer: The public comment period consists of a 30 day time period, where your method is opened up for review by community members who can submit comments, questions and feedback.

faqs.question: Can public comment and peer review happen concurrently?
faqs.answer: Yes, these two processes can be run in parallel.

stepCards.title: Methodology accepted!
stepCards.description: Once it has been confirmed that the methodology developer has addressed each comment or revision request, the methodology will be accepted and move out of its beta form.

peerReviewSection.title: Participate in Methodology Peer Review
peerReviewSection.description: Methodologies submitted to Regen Network will go through a review process to provide valuable feedback which can be used to improve our understanding of the science and techniques/approaches, while promoting scientific transparency and instilling buyer assurance and confidence in claims. This process is in place to promote best practices in MRV and foster both innovation and trust. If you are interested in reviewing methodologies that have been submitted, please contact us at <a href="mailto:science@regen.network">science@regen.network.</a

createCreditClassSection.title: Create a Credit Class
createCreditClassSection.description: If you haven’t yet created a credit class for this methodology, learn more below.

heroSection.title: Create a credit class on Regen Registry.
heroSection.description: Instead of a one-size-fits-all solution, design the ecosystem service credit that works for your constituents, ecological context and use case.

stepCardSection.title: General process for creating a new credit class
stepCardSection.mainDescription: A lot can go into writing a new methodology and it might seem like an overwhelming process, but we’re here to help! Check out our CarbonPlus Grasslands Methodology to get a feel for what a methodology might entail and the various components included, and feel free to email science@regen.network for any additional questions.

stepCards.title: Generate an idea for a credit class and submit a concept note for internal review
stepCards.description: Outline your idea for a new credit class in a short one-page concept note and submit for internal review. We will review and provide you with feedback and guide you to the next step. How much time will it take to write a concept note? A few hours or a couple of days at most. Expected response time: one week.

creditTypeSection.title: Institutional vs. Flex Credits
creditTypeSection.descriptionTop: These credits fit the requirements that institutional buyers are looking for as it relates to GHG accounting and internationally accepted standards including:
creditTypeSection.descriptionBottom: While Institutional  Credits meet the needs institutions look for best-in-class offsets, there are situations that merit more flexibility on the GHG accounting requirements, such as corporate insetting, long standing nature based projects, and local / community engagements. For these and other situations, Credit Designers default to using Flex Credits. That is, when a credit does not meet all of the Institutional  Credit criteria then it is labeled as a Flex Credit.

institutionalCards.title: Independently Verified
institutionalCards.description: All emission reductions and removals shall be verified by an independent 3rd party verifier.

institutionalCards.title: Unique
institutionalCards.description: No more than one carbon credit can be associated with a single emission reduction or removal as 1ton of CO2e.

institutionalCards.title: Additionality
institutionalCards.description: Ensures that GHG emission reductions or removal enhancements generated by the project go beyond what would have happened in the absence of the project.

institutionalCards.title: Real
institutionalCards.description: All carbon reductions and removals and project activities that generate them shall be proven to have genuinely taken place.

institutionalCards.title: Measurable
institutionalCards.description: All emission reductions and removals shall be quantifiable, using recognized measurement tools, including adjustments for uncertainty and leakage, against a credible emissions baseline.

institutionalCards.title: Permanence
institutionalCards.description: Carbon credits shall represent permanent emission reductions and removals.

institutionalCards.title: Reversal
institutionalCards.description: Safeguards shall be in place to ensure that reversal risk is minimized.

flexCreditCards.title: Flexibility
flexCreditCards.description: Provide more flexibility to credit designers in tailoring credits to their needs with fewer limitations on land stewards and project developers.

flexCreditCards.title: Evaluate New Approaches
flexCreditCards.description: Serve to evaluate new nature based approaches, which if proven successful can be later upgraded to Institutional Credits.

flexCreditCards.title: Full Gamut
flexCreditCards.description: Run the full gamut from semi Institutional  Credit to a more bespoke design.

outcomeSection.title: Help develop a range of credit classes for the diversity of nature based solutions
outcomeSection.description: In addition to developing credit classes focused on carbon reduction and removal, we must also work to incorporate protocols to track water cycles, nutrient cycles, biodiversity, pollution management, changing weather patterns, and more.

bottomBanner.title: Create a Methodology
bottomBanner.description: If you haven’t yet created a methodology for this credit class, learn more below.

heroBannerTop.title: Learn more about our methodology review process.
heroBannerTop.description: Methodologies submitted to Regen Registry will undergo a scientific review process to support the adoption of best practices for the monitoring, reporting, and verification of nature based solutions. This process is a great opportunity to work with the scientific community to develop your methodology in a way that fosters innovation and trust.

internalReviewSection.title: Part 1: Internal Review
internalReviewSection.description:
Methodologies submitted to Regen Network Development Inc. will pass through an internal review process to ensure that all the components needed to monitor a nature based solution are included. If your methodology is missing important information needed for the monitoring, reporting and verification, we may ask you to make some upgrades and resubmit. Otherwise your methodology will be accepted in beta form on our website! 

 If you are creating a Flex Methodology, then only an internal review is required.
internalReviewSection.disclaimerBottom: *All time frames are estimations that may vary

externalReviewSection.title: Part 2: External Review Process
externalReviewSection.description: The external review process consists of A) a public comment period and B) a formal scientific peer review where members of the science community and experts in the field can provide feedback on a methodology. The two processes can be run in parallel, and provide methodology designers with the opportunity to address critiques and improve the science backing their methods.
externalReviewSection.disclaimerBottom: *All time frames are estimations that may vary

stepCards.title: Methodology opened on Regen Registry for a 30-day public comment period
stepCards.description: The public comment period is an opportunity for the scientific community to ask questions and provide feedback on a methodology. Questions and comments are compiled into a Feedback Document which is returned to the Methodology Developer.

stepCards.title: Methodology Developer compiles a Revision Report & upgrades methodology
stepCards.description: The Revision Report is an opportunity for the methodology developer to address comments, questions, and revision requests outlined in the public comment or scientific peer review process. The report includes answers to clarifying questions, indications of how comments or revision requests were incorporated into the updated methodology, or explanations of why the comment or revision request was not incorporated.

stepCards.title: Create a methodology draft and submit it for internal review
stepCards.description: Your methodology should aim to outline standards and tools to monitor the ecological, environmental, and social indicators covered by your nature based solution. Your approach can be region specific or cover a wide range of locations.

stepCards.title: Step 1: Scientific advisors review the methodology
stepCards.description: The Methodology Developer identifies a minimum of three scientific advisors which have appropriate training, background, knowledge and qualifications to provide an in-depth review of the submitted methodology. Scientific advisors will review the methodology and provide the Methodology Developer with a Feedback Document with all their comments, questions and revision requests.

faqs.question: Who can be a scientific advisor?
faqs.answer: Some examples of qualifications may include, but are not limited to: a PhD in soil science, ecology, or relevant field of study, expert-level GIS, expert-level data scientist, Remote Sensing Specialist, or technical expert with sectoral knowledge.

faqs.question: What is provided to the scientific advisor?
faqs.answer: The Methodology Developer provides the reviewers with the methodology and any Revision Reports from previous steps.

faqs.question: The timeline says this takes 3-4 weeks, could this be completed in a shorter period of time?
faqs.answer: Yes! The 3-4 week timeline is an estimate on the amount of time it may take to find appropriate reviewers and receive their feedback.

stepCards.title: The Methodology Developer compiles a Revision Report
stepCards.description: The Revision Report is an opportunity for the methodology developer to address comments, questions, and revision requests outlined in the public comment or scientific peer review process. The report includes answers to clarifying questions, indications of how comments or revision requests were incorporated into the updated methodology, or explanations of why the comment or revision request was not incorporated.

stepCards.title: Regen Registry rejects or accepts the methodology
stepCards.description: The Methodology Developer submits the Revision Report to Regen Registry. If Regen Registry confirms that the Revision Report completes the requirements, it will be posted alongside the methodology (which moves out of beta version) and made publicly available. If Regen Registry rejects the methodology, full evaluation documentation will be provided.

faqs.question: Can my method go through multiple review processes?
faqs.answer: Yes! As the science and technology supporting continues to evolve, so should your methods. Whether as a second formal review process, or as a peer review, we encourage you to continue to work together with your peers and continue to upgrade your methods.

faqs.question: Why would a method be rejected?
faqs.answer: Revision Reports reviewed by Regen Registry might be determined incomplete if they did not properly address comments or incorporate revision requests into the upgraded methodology. In this scenario, the methodology will need to be upgraded before acceptance.

heroBannerBottom.title: Create a Methodology
heroBannerBottom.description: Learn more about the ins and outs of creating a new methodology with Regen Registry.

outcomes.title: Carbon sequestration
outcomes.description: Sequestering carbon in SOC is one way to mitigate climate change.

outcomes.title: Above ground biomass
outcomes.description: Increasing all living biomass which is located above the ground.

outcomes.title: Soil health
outcomes.description: Healthy soil acts as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.

outcomes.title: Animal welfare
outcomes.description: Animals play an important role in the maintenance of balance in an ecosystem.

outcomes.title: Ecosystem health
outcomes.description: Robust ecosystems provide a home for humans, plants, and animals to flourish.

outcomes.title: Enhance biodiversity
outcomes.description: The diversity of plants and animals is of vital importance to our well-being.

creditClasses.name: CarbonPlus Grasslands
creditClasses.description: The CarbonPlus Grasslands credit is designed to significantly increase the amount of hectares regeneratively grazed worldwide. The methodology relies on remote sensing to substantially reduce the cost of monitoring carbon sequestration while maintaining location-based scientific rigor.

overviewCards.title: Real
overviewCards.description: All carbon reductions and removals are proven to have genuinely taken place

overviewCards.title: Measurable
overviewCards.description: Emission removal is quantifiable using GIS tools and adjusted for uncertainty

overviewCards.title: Permanent
overviewCards.description: 25 year period through reversal buffer or covenant

overviewCards.title: Additional
overviewCards.description: A new practice adopted from  pre-approved list

overviewCards.title: Leakage
overviewCards.description: De minimis in agricultural land management

overviewCards.title: co-benefits
overviewCards.description: Ecosystem health, animal welfare, and soil health

heroSection.title: Support regenerative ranch management.
heroSection.description: Livestock grazing covers over 3.3 billion hectares, or 25 percent of the world’s land area. Managed grazing practices can reverse land degradation, enhance net carbon sequestration, and improve soil and ecosystem health.

resources.title: CarbonPlus Grasslands Credit Class
resources.description: The standard that defines the specific requirements for the CarbonPlus Grasslands credit.

resources.title: CarbonPlus Grasslands Methodology

steps.title: Qualify via our intake form
steps.description: To qualify, you have already implemented or intend to adopt one of these practices: rotational grazing, holistic grazing, adaptive grazing, or intensive grazing

steps.title: Schedule an introduction
steps.description: Be sure to review these items before the call: Data Requirements and Project Basics.

steps.title: Part 2: Project Implementation
steps.description: You are pre-qualified. Proceed with these steps.

steps.title: Complete a Project Plan
steps.description: The project plan includes details about your land use history, management practices, and more. Download project plan template»

steps.title: Sign contracts
steps.description: To officially start the CarbonPlus Grasslands project, project contracts must be signed.

steps.title: Create a project page
steps.description: This marketing page helps to advertise your project to potential credit buyers, like this project page for Wilmot. See project page template»

steps.title: Collect data & establish a baseline measurement
steps.description: Collect soil samples and have them analyzed by a laboratory. Download the Soil Sampling Guidelines» Submit location-based project data. Download the Data Requirements»

steps.title: Hire a verifier (as required)
steps.description: Hire a third party Verifier to confirm your project information.

steps.title: Issue and sell your credits
steps.description: Issue CarbonPlus credits and sell them via Regen Registry. Use your own broker or sell through the Regen Network brokerage services.

impact.name: Soil Organic Carbon
impact.description: Organic matter contributes to nutrient retention and turnover, soil structure, moisture retention and availability, degradation of pollutants, carbon sequestration and soil resilience.

impact.name: Animal Welfare
impact.description: Animal welfare is an important component in a well managed grazing enterprise. Low stress stock handling techniques have been adopted to ensure animals have higher quality life.

impact.name: Ecosystem Health
impact.description: In the ecological realm, ‘health’ is characterized by system integrity and the exhibition of certain fundamental properties of self-organizing complex systems.

impact.name: Soil Health
impact.description: The capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.

methodologies.name: CarbonPlus Grasslands Methodology
methodologies.description: The Methodology for GHG and Co-Benefits in Grazing Systems provides a holistic assessment of ecological state indicators for grasslands under regenerative grazing practices. Managed grazing, which involves carefully controlling livestock density and intensity of grazing, has been shown to provide a wide range of ecosystem benefits such as enhanced carbon sequestration, improved soil health, and increased water infiltration. This methodology combines remote sensing data with in-field measurements to provide high quality estimates of soil organic carbon stock and measures additional ecological co-benefits such as animal welfare, ecosystem health, and soil health.
methodologies.documentationTitle: GHG & Co-Benefits in Grazing Systems Methodology (Beta)
methodologies.testMethodologyDescription:
Have your own soil samples? Want to learn how this methodology works in your area? So would we! In supporting the movement of #OpenScience, Regen Network Development Inc., hopes to build a community of scientists and land stewards who actively contribute to improving the methods used to monitor ecological landscapes. We encourage anyone interested to contribute to this growing body of knowledge by testing our methodology in your area.

Reach out to us at science@regen.network to share your results!

steps.title: Collect in-field soil samples
steps.description: Soil samples collected at strategic points across the property are tested for soil organic carbon, bulk density, and soil health variables.

faqs.question: How many samples need to be collected?
faqs.answer: The number of samples needed for a project varies with the project size and landscape variability. Larger projects, or projects in more topographically or ecologically complex areas are more likely to have a wide range of soil organic carbon values. An accurate soil carbon assessment relies on collecting enough samples to capture the spatial variability of the soil. Our Sample Size Calculator provides more information.

faqs.question: How are sampling locations determined?
faqs.answer: Variables highly correlated to soil organic carbon are used to stratify the project area using k-means and conditioned latin hypercube (cLHC) algorithms. The resulting stratification is used to assign sampling locations which cover the full range of SOC values. This approach can help reduce the number of samples needed to measure soil carbon by creating a more efficient sampling design.

faqs.question: How are soil samples processed?
faqs.answer: Soil samples are sent to a certified laboratory where they are processed for soil organic carbon, bulk density, and other soil health metrics. Information on lab certifications and regionally approved soil laboratories can be found in our Soil Sampling Resource Guide.

steps.title: Map soil organic carbon
steps.description: Remote sensing data and the lab-tested soil samples are used to estimate soil organic carbon at unsampled locations using statistical models, machine learning, and spatial interpolation.

faqs.question: What is remote sensing?
faqs.answer: Remote sensing is the process of detecting and monitoring the physical characteristics of an area at a distance. Special cameras mounted on satellites or aircrafts collect images which allow researchers to monitor landscapes without having to visit the location of interest.

faqs.question: What remote sensing data is used
faqs.answer: This methodology uses hyperspectral satellite imagery with a spatial resolution of 20 meters or higher (Sentinel-2, PlanetScope, WorldView, etc…). Regionally available digital elevation models (DEMs), soil variability maps, and historical land management data are also included in the soil carbon estimate.

faqs.question: How are remote sensing data used to map soil organic carbon?
faqs.answer: Satellite imagery and other remote sensing data are paired with soil organic carbon values collected in the field, using GPS coordinates recorded at sample locations to tie the datasets together. Statistical models and machine learning algorithms are then fit to this combined dataset and used to predict percent soil organic carbon at unsampled locations.

faqs.question: Is the remote sensing approach always used?
faqs.answer: No. The scalability of the satellite remote sensing approach from the CarbonPlus methodology for GHG and Co-benefits in Grazing Systems is still under research. Presumably, not all grassland areas will have high correlation between soil organic carbon (SOC) and the spectral reflectance of the grasslands surface. Interpolation methods, such as the kriging, inverse distance weighted (IDW), and spline algorithms, are offered as an alternative to the satellite remote sensing approach.

steps.title: Quantify soil organic carbon stock
steps.description: Percent soil organic carbon estimates are combined with bulk density measurements from the field to quantify soil organic carbon stocks and CO2 equivalent stocks.

faqs.question: What’s the difference between percent soil organic carbon and soil organic carbon stocks?
faqs.answer: Percent soil organic carbon indicates the amount of carbon present in the soil, but does not quantify volumetrically how much carbon is being stored.

faqs.question: How are soil organic carbon stocks quantified?
faqs.answer: Soil organic carbon stocks are quantified by multiplying percent SOC by bulk density and soil depth. To ensure proper estimation of soil organic carbon stocks, any man-made objects such as roads or buildings, woody vegetation, bodies of water and other non-grasslands land types are excluded from the stock estimation.

faqs.question: How is bulk density measured?
faqs.answer: Soil samples collected alongside soil carbon samples are tested for bulk density. Spatial interpolation algorithms and pedotransfer functions are used to estimate bulk density at unsampled locations.

faqs.question: What soil depth is used?
faqs.answer: The soil depth used for carbon stock quantification is the depth measured in the soil samples, which should remain consistent across sampling locations.

faqs.question: How are soil organic carbon stocks converted to CO2 equivalent stocks?
faqs.answer: Carbon stored in the soil can not be directly compared to carbon found in GHG emissions. To convert soil organic carbon stocks (tonC) to CO2 equivalent stocks (ton CO2-eq) a conversion factor of 3.67 is used

steps.title: Calculate creditable carbon change
steps.description: Creditable carbon change is calculated by comparing the measured CO2 equivalent stocks to the baseline year. Deductions are made to account for emissions from the project activity, such as methane emissions, and uncertainty from the soil carbon estimate.

faqs.question: How are emissions from grazing livestock accounted for?
faqs.answer: Each monitoring period the number of animal heads within the project area are recorded and multiplied by regional or IPCC sponsored emission factors to calculate Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions.

faqs.question: What is an uncertainty deduction?
faqs.answer: The total uncertainty for a project is the sum of the uncertainties calculated throughout the methodology during a given monitoring period. Sources of uncertainty for creditable carbon stock calculations include percent soil organic carbon estimates, bulk density estimates, and other calculations which could have introduced additional errors.

faqs.question: How are uncertainty deductions applied?
faqs.answer: Uncertainty deductions are scaled to the level of uncertainty. Uncertainty deductions used in this method can be found in Section 3.6.4 of the Methodology for GHG and Co-Benefits in Grazing Systems.

steps.title: Assess co-benefits
steps.description: Soil health, ecosystem health, and animal welfare are assessed using a combination of remote sensing and in-field data to provide a holistic assessment of the project area beyond carbon sequestration.

faqs.question: How is soil health evaluated?
faqs.answer: Soil health is evaluated by comparing the lab measured soil health indicators with local soil health benchmarks. Indicators such as pH, Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium, Calcium and Magnesium are included in the assessment.

faqs.question: How is animal welfare evaluated?
faqs.answer: The Animal Welfare assessment is based on local recommendations to outline specific requirements (such as access to feed and water, facilities, animal handling) and a ranking of each according to current practices.

faqs.question: How is ecosystem health evaluated?
faqs.answer: Ecosystem health is assessed through the use of context-dependent indicators of ecosystem vigor, organization, and resilience.
